full_text: In this demonstration, I show how to simulate a policy change request that results in a reduction in premium. Then we see how BillingCenter allocates the credit from the premium reduction. Here's the Gayle Lohmann account, which has a personal auto policy with a premium amount of $1,200. First, I'll take a look at the invoices for this account. I click the invoices link in the sidebar. The first invoice has been paid in full. There are three other invoices, which are planned and unpaid. Let's assume the policyholder has removed a driver from her personal auto policy, resulting in a premium reduction. I'll simulate what happens in BillingCenter when the $300 premium credit is received. To do this, I'll go to the policy. I click the Actions menu button. And select Change Policy to open the Policy Change Wizard. The Policy Change Wizard is available in a development environment to simulate a policy change billing instruction. There's nothing for me to modify on Step 1. Let's advance to Step 2. I want to create a billing instruction to reduce the premium by $300. I click Add. Since this is a credit, I'll enter minus 300 as the amount. Now I click Finish. Let's take a look at how BillingCenter handled the credit. To see this, I'll go to the Charges screen. The Policy Change Charge is already selected. Let's look at the invoice items that resulted from the charge. The amount column shows the $300 credit was sliced according to the payment plan into three installment items, evenly distributed across the remaining three unpaid invoices. In the Paid Amount column, we see each negative installment item was paid immediately. Paying a negative item makes the money from the credit available to be allocated to unsettled positive items. Next, I'll select the Policy Issuance Charge. Looking at the Paid Amount column on the invoice items, we see the $100 credit amounts have been allocated to pay positive invoice items on the remaining three invoices. Now, let's take a look at the invoices for this account. I click the account number in the info bar. Now I click the invoices link in the sidebar. Notice the amounts for the remaining invoices are for $180 instead of the original $280 amounts. The $300 reduction in premium has been applied to the planned invoices. This concludes our demo on simulating a policy change request that results in a reduction in premium.

segments.text: In this demonstration, I show how to simulate a policy change request that results in a reduction in premium. Then we see how BillingCenter allocates the credit from the premium reduction. Here's the Gayle Lohmann account, which has a personal auto policy with a premium amount of $1,200. First, I'll take a look at the invoices for this account. I click the invoices link in the sidebar. The first invoice has been paid in full. There are three other invoices, which are planned and unpaid.

Let's assume the policyholder has removed a driver from her personal auto policy, resulting in a premium reduction. I'll simulate what happens in BillingCenter when the $300 premium credit is received. To do this, I'll go to the policy. I click the Actions menu button.
And select Change Policy to open the Policy Change Wizard.
The Policy Change Wizard is available in a development environment to simulate a policy change billing instruction. There's nothing for me to modify on Step 1. Let's advance to Step 2.
I want to create a billing instruction to reduce the premium by $300. I click Add. Since this is a credit, I'll enter minus 300 as the amount.
Let's take a look at how BillingCenter handled the credit. To see this, I'll go to the Charges screen.
The Policy Change Charge is already selected.
Let's look at the invoice items that resulted from the charge.
The amount column shows the $300 credit was sliced according to the payment plan into three installment items, evenly distributed across the remaining three unpaid invoices.
In the Paid Amount column, we see each negative installment item was paid immediately. Paying a negative item makes the money from the credit available to be allocated to unsettled positive items.
Next, I'll select the Policy Issuance Charge.
Looking at the Paid Amount column on the invoice items, we see the $100 credit amounts have been allocated to pay positive invoice items on the remaining three invoices.
Now, let's take a look at the invoices for this account. I click the account number in the info bar.
Now I click the invoices link in the sidebar.
Notice the amounts for the remaining invoices are for $180 instead of the original $280 amounts.
The $300 reduction in premium has been applied to the planned invoices.
This concludes our demo on simulating a policy change request that results in a reduction in premium.
